    Sarco/Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium ATPase Inhibitors: Beyond Anticancer Perspective

    • Lucie Peterková
      Lucie Peterková

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The sarco/endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA), which plays a key role in the maintenance of Ca2+ ion homeostasis, is an extensively studied enzyme, the inhibition of which has a considerable impact on cell life and death decision. To date, several SERCA inhibitors have been thoroughly studied and the most notable one, a derivative of the sesquiterpene lactone thapsigargin, is gradually approaching a clinical application. Meanwhile, new compounds with SERCA-inhibiting properties of natural, synthetic, or semisynthetic origin are being discovered and/or developed; some of these might also be suitable for the development of new drugs with improved performance. This review brings an up-to-date comprehensive overview of recently discovered compounds with the potential of SERCA inhibition, discusses their mechanism of action, and highlights their potential clinical applications, such as cancer treatment.

    SPECIAL ISSUE

    This article is part of the Women in Medicinal Chemistry special issue.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The longstanding interest in sarco/endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) inhibitors began due to their utilization in studies dealing with Ca2+ ion homeostasis and endoplasmic reticulum stress response. Over time, their therapeutic potential, e.g., for cancer treatment, has been unraveled. SERCA inhibition has even been proposed as a possible cause for the antimalarial effect of artemisinin. Although a considerable number of SERCA inhibitors have been identified, only few of them have been extensively studied and developed further. Moreover, several SERCA-inhibiting compounds are already established as drugs due to their other biological activities or have undergone multiple clinical trials for various indications (Tables 1 and 2).
    Table 1. Clinical Trials of Selected SERCA Inhibitors Tested for Cancer Treatmenta

    2. Sarco/Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium ATPase

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is an organelle playing a vital role in multiple cellular processes. Besides its role in protein and lipid synthesis, it serves as a storage depot for calcium ions, which affect most cell processes. Not only are calcium ions essential for proper protein folding, but they also act as a second messenger in cell signaling.(1) Ca2+ ion homeostasis is fundamental to the cell survival since prolonged imbalance of Ca2+ ion concentration results in ER stress presented as the unfolded-protein response (UPR) followed by mitochondrial uptake of Ca2+ ions and subsequent activation of proapoptotic signaling.(2,3)
    Although multiple receptors participate in calcium signaling [reviewed in refs (1) and (4)], the maintenance of calcium ion homeostasis (submicromolar Ca2+ concentration in cytoplasm vs millimolar in the ER)(5) within the ER is predominantly governed by the SERCA enzyme.(6)
    In humans and other vertebrates, SERCA proteins are encoded by three genes, namely, ATP2A1, ATP2A2, and ATP2A3 (GenBank). These three genes give rise to 12 SERCA isoforms, the expression of which is tissue-dependent.(7,8) SERCA1a, a splice variant of ATP2A1, prevails in striated muscle cells(8) (reviewed in great detail in ref (9)), while the expression of SERCA2a is predominant in the myocardium, smooth muscle, and nonmuscle tissues.(10) SERCA2b, a splice variant of ATP2A2, is a constitutively expressed “house-keeping” SERCA isoform,(11) although SERCA3 isoforms are coexpressed with SERCA2b.(10,12) RNA gene expression patterns of individual isoforms can be found at the BioGPS database. SERCA is a 110 kDa transmembrane protein consisting of 10 transmembrane helices (11 in case of SERCA2b) and three globular cytoplasmic domains; its crystallographic structure is well-known. Up to now, at least 50 structures of SERCA proteins, mostly from the European rabbit (Oryctolagus cuniculus) but also from pig(13) (Sus scrofa) and cow (Bos taurus), are available in the Protein Data Bank database (https://www.rcsb.org/) with resolution ranging between 2.2 and 4.0 Å. To date, two structures of human SERCA2b (5ZTF and 6JJU) have been published.(14) The SERCA protein holds two calcium ion binding sites between four of the transmembrane helices (M4, M5, M6, and M8). The three cytosolic domains, nucleotide-binding (N), actuator (A), and phosphorylating (P), interact with ATP and move during ion transport.(15,16) In spite of the number of SERCA isoforms, they are all highly homologous; the largest variability is present at their C-terminal regions. Interestingly, the individual isoforms(17) also share similar affinity for calcium ions, except for SERCA2b, which binds calcium ions with greater affinity but transports them more slowly, likely due to one extra transmembrane helix and a luminal extension of its polypeptide chain(18,19) which may serve as a regulator of SERCA2b activity.(14)
    SERCA is a P-type ATPase, also known as E1-E2 ATPase, since it interconverts between at least two conformational states E1 and E2, the mechanism of which has been well described.(20) In the E1 state, this ATPase is activated by binding of two calcium ions in the cavities among the M4, M5, M6, and M8 helices. This is followed by phosphorylation using ATP, the free energy of which is spent on the conformational change into the E2 state associated with a release of the two calcium ions into the ER lumen. Furthermore, upon the initial binding of two Ca2+ ions, two to three protons are countertransported from luminal to the cytosolic site during SERCA dephosphorylation from previous transport cycle. This process returns SERCA to its E1 state, accompanied by a rearrangement of the cytoplasmic domains as well as of 6 out of 10 transmembrane helices.(9,20−23)
    Since Ca2+ ions play a death–survival decision role in a cell, it is crucial to ensure tight SERCA regulation on multiple levels (recently reviewed in ref (24)). This is mediated by SERCA expression as well as the SERCA-inhibiting micropeptides phospholamban (PLN),(25) sarcolipin (SLN),(26) myoregulin (MRLN),(27) endoregulin (ELN), and another-regulin (ALN).(28) In addition to that, a study by Nelson et al.(29) revealed SERCA regulation by a small open reading frame (smORF) peptide called dwarf coded by a long noncoding RNA, which enhances the activity of SERCA by displacing the micropeptide inhibitors.
    As aforementioned, SERCA’s activity is vital for the maintenance of Ca2+ ion homeostasis in the cytosol and the ER, through which SERCA controls to a large extent the cell fate. This makes it a valuable target for development of novel inhibitors with distinct therapeutic potential. A number of SERCA inhibitors are being discovered every year and comprise a set of very diverse molecules, some of them belonging to natural products, others being their semisynthetic or drug-based derivatives. They also differ in their mechanism of action and degree of SERCA inhibition. In the next sections, we focus on the most important ones.

    3. Terpenoid SERCA Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    3.1. Thapsigargin and Trilobolide: The Most Auspicious SERCA Inhibitors

    Of all SERCA inhibitors, thapsigargin (1, Figure 1) is the most well-known and thoroughly described representative. Compound 1 is a guaianolide-type sesquiterpene lactone isolated from the plant Thapsia garganica (Apiaceae), native to the Mediterranean. The mechanism of SERCA inhibition by compound 1 was described in the 1990s. Compound 1 inhibits SERCA in a stoichiometric, noncompetitive, and irreversible manner(30,31) by binding to its M3 transmembrane helix(31) in the cavity among the M3, M5, and M7 helices(32) (Figure 2). The binding of compound 1 is accomplished through an interaction with SERCA amino acid residues Phe-256 (M3)(32,33) along with Ile-765 (M5) and Tyr-837 (M7). Of these three amino acid residues, Phe-256 is the most important since it constitutes the specific interaction site for compound 1. Even though its substitution does not affect SERCA inhibition by other compounds, such as 2,5-di(tert-butyl)hydroquinone (2, Figure 1, section 5.1),(32) it causes cell resistance to compound 1.(33) The binding of compound 1 stabilizes the enzyme in its E2 state, which prevents the Ca2+ ATPase activation by calcium ions,(34) although it may still be dephosphorylated.(35)
    The ability of compound 1 to increase the cytoplasmic Ca2+ ion level was first observed in human platelet cells,(41) and gradually, compound 1 has been implemented in studies related to ER stress and disruption of calcium ion homeostasis (reviewed in refs (42) and (43)). Nowadays, it serves as a standard tool for calcium signaling research. Importantly, the perturbation of the intracellular [Ca2+] induced by compound 1 can direct cells toward apoptosis regardless of their cell cycle phase they find themselves in,(44) which could be advantageous particularly for the chemotherapy of slowly growing tumors and the idea of compound 1 (protein interaction partners in Figure 3) as drug lead took hold. The fact that the activity of compound 1 is not tissue-specific led later to the development of prodrug derivatives for tissue-specific targeting. The modification of compound 1 consisted of targeting peptides cleavable by a tissue-specific protease, prostate specific antigen (PSA), thus releasing the active drug(44,45) in the prostate. For a more detailed description of the development of this drug, mipsagargin/G-202 (3, Figure 3), which completed phases I and II of clinical trials on solid tumor treatment (Table 1), see refs (46−49). However, it was found recently that not only SERCA but also the Ca2+/Mn2+ ATPase of Golgi apparatus, SPCA1, is inhibited by compound 1, its derivatives, and other SERCA inhibitors.(50) This obviously changes the paradigm of compound 1 as a highly selective SERCA inhibitor and could potentially result in off-target effects in compound 1-based therapy. According to molecular docking, compound 1 and its derivatives bind to SPCA1 via a compound 1-binding pocket homologous to that of SERCA. Furthermore, for 1, 2 (section 5.1), cyclopiazonic acid (4, Figure 3, section 5.2), and bisphenol (5, Figure 3), the IC50 values for SPCA1 were of low micromolar concentrations but significantly higher than that for SERCA in the cases of compounds 1, 2, and 4 and comparable for compound 5.
    A considerable amount of information about compound 1 was amassed throughout recent decades. A concise insight into the molecular action of compound 1 regarding possible and already known protein interaction partners could be provided by computer prediction of functional association networks in the STITCH 5.0 database (Figure 4, http://stitch.embl.de/). The gene products affected by compound 1 range from the above-mentioned SERCAs to caspases 3 and 12 as well as other genes related to UPR, programmed cell death, and immune response (Table 1 in Supporting Information).
    As the demand for compound 1 and its derivatives has been instantly growing, natural resource does not suffice. A significant effort has already been made in order to develop a synthetic route for compound 1 production, which, however, comprises as many as 42 steps with an average yield of 88.6% per step; therefore, the final yield provides only 0.6%.(51,52) Later, a semisynthetic approach utilizing a natural product nortrilobolide (6, Figure 5) was developed.(53) Compound 6 is commonly found in plants of the Apiaceae genera Thapsia as well as Laser(54,55) and is also a potent inhibitor of SERCA.(56) The transformation of compound 6 to compound 1 can be done in only four steps with the overall yield of 21%.(53) Even more efficient and scalable strategies for compound 1 (as well as 6) synthesis have been described,(57,58) the latter of which used commercially available (R)-(−)-carvone as a starting material. The total syntheses were run in 12 steps (and 10 for compound 6) with 5.8% (and 13.3%) overall yield. The laborious synthesis of compound 1 could also be overcome by another approach, which was published by López et al.,(59) who established in vitro shoot cultures with higher yields of compounds 1 and 6 in comparison to leaves and stems of wild T. garganica. This technique for sustainable production of sesquiterpenoids is convenient at an industrial scale and overcomes difficulties associated with traditional field cultivation.
    By structure and biological activity, the most related SERCA inhibitor(60) to compound 1 is trilobolide (7, Figure 6, Table 3). This guaianolide type of sesquiterpene lactone was first isolated from horse caraway Laser trilobum (L.) Borkh (Apiaceae).(61) The hydroxyl groups of compound 7 are the key factor for SERCA inhibition as desoxytrilobolide does not show inhibitory activity.(60) Compound 7 inhibits SERCA with the efficacy equivalent to that of compound 1(56) (Table 3), as a consequence of which compound 7 has been also considered suitable for drug development. To better understand the biological properties of compound 7, a number of biologically active fluorescent green-emitting compound 7-BODIPY derivatives were prepared by an azide–alkyne Huisgen cycloaddition (copper-catalyzed “click chemistry”) approach.(62,63) Two of these conjugates have proven to be biologically active in a slightly decreased manner (cytotoxicity against cancer cells, nitric oxide production) compared to the parent compound. Compound 7-BODIPYs (compounds 8 and 9, Figure 6) localized in the ER of several cancer cell lines caused ER stress and mitochondrial fragmentation probably induced by the elevated calcium ion concentration in cytosol, as unmodified compound 7 does. Moreover, the preservation of biological activity of compounds 8 and 9 was further confirmed by stimulation of cytokine secretion in rat peritoneal cells.(62,63) This study was followed by development of a traceable drug delivery system for compound 7 consisting of compound 7-BODIPY and cholesterol packed in liposomes composed of dipalmitoyl-3-trimethylammoniumpropane and phosphatidylethanolamine.(64) Furthermore, since porphyrins can be employed in photodynamic therapy of cancer, a multimodal therapy approach consisting of a combination of cytotoxic compound 7 with a photosensitive agent (photosensitizer) is a path worth exploring. Therefore, conjugation with porphyrins resulted in fluorescent red-emitting compound 7 derivatives, which showed partial loss of cytotoxic activity compared to unmodified compound 7, although interestingly in increased nitric oxide production, which compound 7 also modulates.(65) Besides the conjugates of compound 7 with porphyrins and BODIPY, a series of compound 7-steroid (estradiol, pregnene, dehydroepiandrosterone, and testosterone) conjugates were prepared in order to selectively target steroid-sensitive cancer cells to overcome the fact that SERCA is expressed in all tissues. Two of the derivatives, compound 7 with pregnene (10, Figure 6) and with estradiol (11, Figure 6), have shown a strong cytotoxic effect and preferential selectivity for cancer cells while live-cell microscopy revealed the impact on ER and mitochondria, causing their stress response. Furthermore, compound 11 and compound 7 with testosterone (12, Figure 6) showed antimycobacterial activity against Mycobacterium bovis with IC50 (half maximal inhibitory concentration) values equal to 10.6 and 27.3 μM, respectively.(66) The IC50 values of compound 11 were within the range of 10.2–15.3 μM for cancer cell lines, with the exception of MIA PaCa-2 cells (IC50 > 50 μM); for primary fibroblasts (BJ and MRC-5), the IC50 values of compound 11 were slightly increased (IC50 of 17.0 μM) and similar (IC50 of 10.1 μM), respectively. In the case of compound 12, the IC50 values were overall higher and more diverse in cancer cell lines ranging from 13.7 μM to more than 50 μM and were greater than 50 μM in primary cells (MRC-5, BJ).(66) Although compound 11 was quite active against M. bovis, its further development is hindered by the fact that it also retained its estrogenic activity at low micromolar concentrations. These data nevertheless indicate that compound 7 may be conjugated with bulky moieties such as steroids while still retaining some of its cytotoxic activity. This may broaden the spectrum of moieties worth considering for compound targeting, and in the future it could lead to development of novel drugs.
    Table 3. Activity of SERCA Inhibitors

    Nonylphenol0.35–6 μMRabbit SERCA1a (purified and microsomes) mouse testicular microsomes (SERCA2b/3) (88,89)
    Orthovanadate10–100 μMChicken cerebellar microsomes (90)
    Paxillin5 μMRabbit skeletal muscle microsomes (SERCA1a)33(91)
    Porcine cerebellar microsomes (SERCA2b)
    Porcine cardiac microsomes (SERCA2a)
    Human platelet microsomes (SERCA2b/3)
    Peptide M3910.3 μMPurified rabbit skeletal muscle SERCA1a (92)
    Quercetin9 μMRabbit skeletal muscle microsomes (SERCA1a)40(70)
    Porcine cerebellar microsomes (SERCA2b)
    Rapamycin77 μMPurified rabbit SERCA1a58(84)
    Porcine cerebellar microsomes
    Porcine cardiac microsomes
    sHA 14-1d23 μMRabbit skeletal muscle microsomes (SERCA1a)70(93)
    Porcine brain microsomes (SERCA2b)
    Tetrabromobisphenol A0.5–2.3 μMRabbit skeletal muscle microsomes SERCA1a52(94)
    Porcine cerebellar microsomes SERCA2b
    Thapsigargin0.21–12 nMRabbit SERCA1b1(69)
    Human SERCA2b
    Human SERCA3a (microsomal membranes, recombinant expression)
    Trifluoroperazine45 μMPurified rabbit SERCA1a61(76)
    Porcine cerebellar microsomes (SERCA2b)
    Trilobolide∼20 nMPurified rabbit SERCA1a7(60)
    Zuelaguidin C7.5 μMSERCA1a purified from rabbit SR vesicles22(39)
    a

    no. = number of a compound in correspondence as it is mentioned in the main text.

    b

    7-Chloro-5-(2-chlorophenyl)-1,5-dihydro-4,1-benzothiazepin-2(3H)-one.

    c

    Ethyl 2-amino-6-(3,5-dimethoxyphenyl)-4-(2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-4H-chromene-3-carboxylate.

    d

    Ethyl-2-amino-6-phenyl-4-(2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-4H-chromene-3-carboxylate.

    Besides the SERCA inhibiting activity, both compounds 1 and 7 are known to possess immunomodulation properties, thus affecting the production of nitric oxide(95−99) and cytokines. Specifically, both sesquiterpenes induce secretion of interferon-γ(97,100−102) and IL-2(101) in macrophages in submicromolar or low micromolar concentrations. Currently, Kim et al.(103) have published results on T cells stimulated by compound 1. In this type of immune cell, compound 1 is inducer of IL-2 at nanomolar concentrations. At micromolar concentrations, compound 1 inhibits IL-2 production and T cell proliferation. These data further increase the appeal to study these natural products and expand the range of their possible applications.

    3.2. Other Terpenoids and Their SERCA-Inhibiting Activity

    Besides the sesquiterpene lactone compound 1, T. garganica was found to seasonally contain also another type of terpenoid compounds, C-19 dilactones, which were subsequently named basiliolides.(104) A similar type of terpenoid compounds was also at the same time isolated from another plant of the Thapsia genus, T. transtagana, and the compounds were named transtaganolides.(105) Different names reflect the plant of origin or, in case of basiliolides, the place of collection of the T. garganica. Furthermore, some of the compounds from the two groups differ in their pattern of the 3-carboxyl oxygen bridge, which binds to C-15 in the cases of transtaganolides A (13, Figure 7) and B (14, Figure 7) and to C-10 in the cases of basiliolides A1 (15, Figure 7) and A2, which are identical to transtaganolides C and D(104,105) (Figure 1). Compared to compound 1, basiliolides are more polar and structurally different, but they also inhibit SERCA from sea urchin calcium stores similarly to compound 1.(104) Further investigation by Navarrete et al.(106) showed that compound 15 is unable to induce apoptosis in Jurkat cells, which can be successfully accomplished by compound 1.(107) Therefore, the modulatory effect of compound 15 on increasing intracellular calcium levels is most likely caused by reversible SERCA inhibition as well as the entry of extracellular Ca2+ ions due to the activation of store-operated calcium release-activated Ca2+ channels (CRAC).(106) Further biological activity of basiliolides also includes the activation of the nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT), nuclear factor κ-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cells (NF-κB), and activator protein 1 (AP-1). A considerable effort has also been invested into the organic synthesis of basiliolides as well as transtaganolides.(108−111) Successful syntheses of basiliolide B (16, Figure 7),(112,113) transtaganolides A, B, C, and D,(114) compound 15, basiliolides A2 and C(115) were reported, suggesting that obtaining transtaganolides and basiliolides for further biological studies does not need to rely on plant isolates from seasonal plants.
    Yet other guaianolide-type sesquiterpene lactones with SERCA-inhibiting properties were isolated from the root of T. villosa:(116) 2,10,11-triacetoxy-8-(3-methylthiopropanoyloxy)slov-3-enolide (17, Figure 8) and 10β,11α-diacetoxy-8α-(2-methylbutanoyloxy)-2β-hydroxyslov-3-enolide (18, Figure 8), which were 20 and 8 times less potent SERCA inhibitors than compound 1, respectively. Alongside them, compound 13 and thapsivillosin B (19, Figure 8) were found to be somewhat less potent SERCA inhibitors than compound 1 whereas thapsitranstagin (20, Figure 8) showed EC50 similar to that of compound 1.(116)
    Not only SL terpenoids show SERCA-inhibiting properties. Tricyclic clerodane diterpenes (TCDs; reviewed in ref (117)), isolated from tropical trees such as Zuelania guidonia(118) or those of the Casearia genus (all from the family Salicaceae, tribe Samydeae),(119,120) are also cytotoxic natural compounds.(119) Recently, their structural analogy to compound 1 was noticed based on in silico evaluation, and subsequently, the ability of some TCDs such as casearborin D (21, Figure 8), zuelaguidin C (22, Figure 8), and casearin J (23, Figure 8) to inhibit SERCA was experimentally proven, along with showing TCDs selectivity toward SERCA out of various P-type ATPases.(39) Compounds 21–23 showed binding activity to SERCA of 2, 7.5, and 10.1 μM, respectively, (0.2 nM for compound 1). Altogether, from 11 tested TCDs, 10 showed some degree of SERCA-inhibiting activity. Moreover, docking experiments suggest that these compounds bind SERCA in the compound 1-binding cavity, with Phe-256 and Phe-834 being the key interaction partners for analyzed TCDs. TCD moieties mediating SERCA inhibition were also identified. Furthermore, SERCA was also confirmed as an important, though probably not the only, target responsible for the TCD cytotoxicity(39) observed in human leukemic lymphoblasts (CCRF-CEM).(118) Therefore, TCDs comprise a new interesting group of cytotoxic and SERCA-inhibiting compounds with anticancer potential.
    Terpenoid SERCA inhibitors may be found even in marine organisms; agelasine B (24, Figure 9), a toxin isolated from the marine sponge Agelas clathrodes (Agelasidae) and other Agelas species,(121) was recently found to cause SERCA inhibition in a dose-dependent manner with IC50 value of 5.58 μM. Compound 24 also induced apoptosis of the breast cancer cells MCF-7 with similar IC50 value to that found for SERCA inhibition.(122) Compound 24 was previously identified as an inhibitor of Na+/K+ ATPase (IC50 values of 11–29 μM).(123)
    A triterpene with SERCA-inhibiting and cytotoxic properties is alisol B (25, Figure 10), a protostane compound isolated from the traditional Chinese medicinal herb Alisma orientale. Alisol B induces autophagy, apoptosis, and UPR due to mobilizing of intracellular [Ca2+] stores and inhibiting SERCA activity with IC50 value of 53 ± 6 μM.(72) Autophagy and apoptosis-inducing activity related to SERCA inhibition were also observed for saikosaponin D (26, Figure 10),(124−127) a triterpenoid saponin with several biological activities isolated from Bupleurum falcatum L. (Apiaceae). Compound 26 showed an IC50 value of ∼10 μM in HeLa cells, while the IC50 value for purified SERCA was ∼50 μM.(126) Recently, it was found that while 3 μM compound 26 significantly elevates intracellular [Ca2+] in primary neurons, at 30 μM concentration, it causes only approximately 10% and 18% SERCA1 and -2 inhibition, respectively,(128) suggesting that SERCA inhibition is likely not the cause of compound 26’s effect on intracellular [Ca2+] and its cytotoxicity.

    4. Plasmodial SERCA Orthologue PfATP6

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Malaria is a considerable problem for developing countries in tropical areas, and the sesquiterpene lactone artemisinin (27, Figure 11, and its derivatives), the discovery of which was awarded by the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2015 (shared with researchers who also discovered antiparasitic compounds of the avermectin family), is being employed as a part of a combination therapy.(129,130) Recent occurrence of compound 27 resistance(131−133) in the areas of use of the combination therapy prompted further investigation into its mechanism of action, and PfATP6 (calcium ATPase-encoded by Plasmodium falciparum) was identified as a potential target for the activity of compound 27. To date, PfATP6 remains among the genes evaluated in relation to resistance to compound 27-based antimalarial therapy.(134,135) Compound 27 shows a small degree of structural similarity to compound 1, while PfATP6 shares 46% homology with mammalian SERCA(136) and is less sensitive to compound 1 than mammalian SERCA.(137−140) The inhibitory activity of compound 27 against PfATP6 and a competitive effect toward compound 1 were first reported in 2003 by Eckstein-Ludwig et al.(141) Subsequently, Leu-263 of PfATP6 was determined as the crucial amino acid for PfATP6 inhibition by artemisinins.(142,143) The Leu-263 in PfATP6 corresponds to Glu-255 of SERCA1a, which is a part of the binding site of compound 1. The PfATP6 L263E mutation was found to abolish the inhibitory effect of compound 27, while E255L mutation of mammalian SERCA increased its susceptibility to compound 27.(142) Further evaluation of PfATP6 L263E showed, however, no significant change in the sensitivity of compound 27.(144) The effect of PfATP6 L263E mutation on the parasites’ sensitivity to artemisinins also varied, as reflected by distinct IC50 values.(144) Recombinant expression of mutant mammalian SERCA1a E255L in COS-1 cells and yeast was also evaluated. The mutant maintained sensitivity to compound 1 inhibition; however, no compound 27 inhibition was detected.(138) These findings were reinforced by Arnou et al.(137) showing that while PfATP6 produced in Saccharomyces cerevisiae is sensitive to compound 4, another SERCA inhibitor reviewed hereinafter in section 5.2, its sensitivity toward compounds 1 and 2 (section 5.1) is negligible while its sensitivity to compound 27 inhibition is almost nonexistent. Furthermore, compound 27 showed even lower binding affinity to PfATP6 than compound 1.(137) A thorough reevaluation of some of the experiments describing the inhibition of PfATP6 by compound 27(141,142) was therefore performed putting the alleged inhibitory activity of artemisinins toward PfATP6 and SERCA1a E255L into question.(145) These findings indicate that PfATP6 is highly unlikely to be the target for compound 27, which is further supported by mutation studies.(146) Another recent study based on modeling of molecular dynamics,(147) though, suggests that a compound 27 adduct with an iron ion may cause significant conformational changes in PfATP6 leading to its inhibition. Activation of compound 27 by iron results in generation of reactive oxygen species,(148) which is considered as one of the possible modes of compound 27 action, although the exact mechanism has not been described. Recent research evaluating the knockout of the PfATP6 functional homologue in S. cerevisiae, Pmr1, indicates a role for Pmr1 in compound 27 activation by iron. The compound 27 treatment results in ROS formation, and interestingly, S. cerevisiae mutants with deletion of Pmr1 were more resistant to compound 27-induced ROS formation than wild type S. cerevisiae.(148) These findings further support the ROS-formation hypothesis over compound 1-like PfATP6 inhibition as the likely mechanism of compound 27 action. ROS formation is also thought to be behind the anticancer activity of compound 27 (for a recent review, see refs (149) and (150)).
    Whereas compound 27 was not proven as an inhibitor of the SERCA orthologue, PfATP6, several terpenoid compounds have thus far been discovered that act as PfATP6 inhibitors, suggesting that PfATP6 may remain a target for newly designed antimalarial drugs. For example, recently identified ent-kaurane diterpenes showed both antiplasmodial activity(151) and inhibitory activity toward PfATP6.(136) The ent-kaurane diterpenes were isolated from the plant Wedelia paludosa DC (Asteraceae), a Brazilian medicinal plant. Cytotoxicity and antiplasmodial activity of three natural ent-kaurane terpenoids, kaurenoic acid (28, Figure 12), isokaurenoic acid (29, Figure 12), and grandiflorenic acid (30, Figure 12), as well as their synthetic derivatives were evaluated in several tumor cell lines and in the chloroquine resistant clone W2 of P. falciparum. Some of the prepared derivatives showed antiplasmodial activity within the low micromolar range, while their cytotoxicity against human liver cancer cells (Hep G2) was ∼100 times lower (antiplasmodial IC50 value of compound 21 was 10.4 ± 2.9 μM compared to cytotoxic concentration CC50 value of 1238.5 ± 200.6 μM), showing also a reasonable selectivity toward P. falciparum.(151) A subsequent computer docking study of the three most promising ent-kaurane derivatives done by the same group indicates that PfATP6 could be the target of ent-kauranes in P. falciparum, yielding similar binding energies to SERCA as compound 1 and even greater binding energies in the case of PfATP6.(136) This is also a hopeful sign that while drug resistance is a growing issue in the malaria treatment, new nature-derived compounds counteracting it may be found.
    Second, a semisynthetic triterpene derivative of betulinic acid, N-{3-[4-(3-aminopropyl)piperazinyl]propyl}-3-O-acetylbetulinamide (LAFIS13, 31, Figure 13), not only has antiplasmodial and cytotoxic activity(152) (designated there as compound 1c) but was also successfully docked into both SERCA and PfATP6 models with even more negative free binding energy than compound 1 showed for mammalian SERCA.(153) Therefore, even though PfATP6 is likely not part of the molecular mechanism behind compound 27 antiplasmodial activity, PfATP6 could be further exploited as a target of a new generation of antimalarials.

    5. Non-Terpenoid SERCA Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    5.1. Hydroquinones

    The best known non-terpenoid SERCA inhibitor from the group of hydroquinones is compound 2 (in Figure 1, IC50 value of 0.4 μM, Table 3).(60,69,154,155) This compound has little in common with the group of SLs except for its hydrophobicity and a presence of hydroxyl groups. In fact, compound 2 is closely related to the food additive tert-butylhydroquinone (also labeled as E319), which is used as lipid antioxidant as the hydroxyl groups are redox active and the molecule may be oxidized to a quinone.(156) Nevertheless, the mechanism of compound 2 binding to SERCA has been extensively studied since 1980s.(60,155,157−159) Comparable to compound 1, compound 2 inhibits SERCA in its E2 conformation(131) but in a reversible manner. The hydroxyls contained in the structure of compound 2 are important for its inhibitory activity(60) since their methylation or other derivatization results in compound 2 inactivation.(60,155) Compound 2 binds to M1 and M4 helices of SERCA (Figure 2) by means of hydrogen bonds between its hydroxyls and Asp-59 (M1), respectively Pro-308 (M4). Compound 2 blocks the binding of calcium ions rather than stabilizing the enzyme conformation and utilizes a different binding site than compound 1.(159) The tert-butyl side chains are also fundamental to the inhibitory effect by means of interaction with Leu-61 and Leu-311, respectively Leu-61, Val-62, and Leu-65.(159) Increasing the size of the alkyls on the hydroquinone structure significantly decreases the IC50 value of such derivatives in comparison to compound 2 likely due to the restricted size of the interaction cavity. Decreasing the size of the alkyl in compound 2 also diminishes the SERCA inhibitory activity, causing insufficient interaction and failing to provide the translocation of Glu-309 which then causes a steric hindrance to Ca2+ ion binding.(154,155,159) Numerous attempts to prepare compound 2 derivatives by modification of hydroquinone side chains were made in the past years.(160,161) It was disproved that two substituents are necessary for the SERCA-inhibiting activity of the hydroquinone, and mono- and disubstituted compounds with IC50 values in the low micromolar range were synthesized. Most recently, derivatives of compound 2 with altered side chains have been synthesized following a similar rationale as the preparation of the peptide-masked compound 1 derivatives and yielding one promising compound tert-butyl (1-((6-(4-(tert-butyl)-2,5-dihydroxyphenyl)hexyl)amino)-4-methyl-1-oxopentan-2-yl)carbamate(162) (32, Figure 14).
    However, the specificity of compound 2 inhibition of SERCA has been called into question since it was discovered that compound 2 is also capable to inhibit the L-type calcium channel at SERCA-inhibiting concentrations. Therefore, the effect of compound 2 studied in rat ventricular myocytes is not surely SERCA-specific.(163−165) It remains to be elucidated if derivatization of the compound 2 structure could resolve this issue. Nevertheless, in the meantime, novel SERCA-inhibiting hydroquinone and phenolic compounds were identified based on quantitative structure–activity relationship (QSAR) modeling.(166)
    Although the specificity of compound 2 as SERCA inhibitor is not absolute, recently, SERCA inhibitors 1 and 2 were also found to significantly increase the lifespan of Caenorhabditis elegans.(167) Particularly compound 2 as a reversible SERCA inhibitor, but also compound 1 as irreversible one, changed the lifespan in a bell-shaped concentration manner of both wild type and caloric restriction eat-2 mutant of C. elegans, highlighting the multipotentiality of calcium signaling modulation and the importance of its research.

    5.2. Cytotoxic Alkaloids

    Among the non-terpenoid compounds, certain alkaloids were identified to possess SERCA-inhibiting properties. Paxillin (33, Figure 15) is an indole alkaloid and mycotoxin produced by Penicillinum paxii. Although known and used also as an inhibitor of the large-conductance Ca2+-activated K+ channel [BKCa],(168) compound 33 inhibits SERCA with an IC50 value of 5 μM or higher, depending on the SERCA isoform.(91)
    The plant-derived benzophenanthridine alkaloid chelerythrine (34, Figure 16), a known protein kinase C (PKC) inhibitor(169) with cytotoxic activity,(170) is also capable of inhibiting SERCA with an IC50 value of 1.5 μM, and SERCA inhibition could be to some extent responsible for cytotoxicity of compound 34.(79)
    A more well-known SERCA inhibitor is compound 4 (Figure 3), a mycotoxin first isolated from Penicillium cyclopium Westling.(171) However, it is produced also by many other species of the Penicillium and Aspergillus genera(172) and often is found as a food contaminant.(173) Structurally, compound 4 is related to ergoline alkaloids, a diverse group of bioactive compounds found in lower fungi and some plants.(174) Compound 4 was first found to inhibit the uptake of Ca2+ ions into muscular sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) and also to induce its discharge.(175,176) The inhibition of SERCA by compound 4 is almost stoichiometric, although the effect is ATP-dependent.(177) Interestingly, compound 4 is a more potent SERCA inhibitor at lower ATP concentrations (0.5–2 μM). Compound 4 also decreases binding activity of ATP to SERCA.(178) Therefore, similar to compound 1, compound 4 induces cellular apoptosis as a result of perturbed Ca2+ ion homeostasis.(179) The Ca2+-free structure of SERCA bound to compound 4(180) showed that the compound 4 binding site is located between the M1–M4 transmembrane helices (Figure 2). Although the compound 4 binding site does not overlap with the compound 1 binding site, both domains are close enough to be affected by similar mutations in the S3 stalk segment extending from M3.(181) In addition, the compound 4 binding site blocks the Ca2+ channel as well as prevents Ca2+ ion binding by stabilizing the M1–M2 helices.(180) According to a structure–activity relationship (SAR) study, the tetrameric ring in compound 4 is indispensable for its SERCA-inhibiting activity, the acyl part being the most important.(182) A subsequent study showed that the indole ring has only a minor effect on the SERCA inhibition since the inhibiting activity of structurally simplified compound 4 derivatives depend on the presence of the C, D, and E rings.(183) Besides discerning of the SAR, new synthetic routes for compound 4 preparation have been developed.(182,184−187) While the inhibition of mammalian SERCA by compound 4 is well-established, it was recently found that compound 4 can potently inhibit also the SERCA orthologue PfATP6.(137,188) Unfortunately, the lack of compound 4 selectivity toward PfATP6 impedes its application as an antimalarial drug. However, suggestions of how to modify the structure of compound 4 in order to decrease its activity toward mammalian SERCA were recently published.(188) Furthermore, a new method to monitor Ca2+ in P. falciparum was developed using genetically encoded Ca2+ sensor.(189) These findings could also provide some ideas on how to tackle the persistent problem of Plasmodium resistance to currently available antimalarial drugs. Moreover, compound 4 was found to inhibit the Bacillus cereus SERCA orthologue BACCA1 at concentrations similar to those effective against mammalian SERCA1a, and a mutational study has recently identified the amino acid residues vital to compound 4 inhibition of bacterial SERCA orthologues of Lactococcus lactis and Listeria monocytogenes.(190) Therefore, compound 4 might serve as a new hope for antibacterial drug development.

    5.3. Cytotoxic Macrolides

    Another example are biselyngbyasides, cytotoxic macrolides isolated from the marine cyanobacterium Lyngbya sp. which show significant toxicity toward a number of cancer cell lines.(191,192) Discovery of the first biselyngbyaside(191) (35, Figure 17) was followed by several more,(192) and subsequently, SERCA was identified as their cellular target.(73) The inhibitory constant (Ki) of biselyngbyaside for SERCA1a is 19 nM, which is 200 times higher than for compound 1 (11 nM for SERCA2a), and Ki of biselyngbyolide B (36, Figure 17) is 17 nM (27 nM for SERCA2a). Not all biselyngbyasides are strong SERCA inhibitors; for example, biselyngbyaside C (37, Figure 17) showed much lower affinity (Ki of 18 μM) for SERCA1a as well as for SERCA2a (Ki of 1.3 μM). Moreover, crystal structures of SERCA1a with biselyngbyasides were also obtained showing that the biselyngbyaside binding site is located between the transmembrane helices M1–4 and that the P1 helix of the cytoplasmic P domain and does not overlap with the compound 1-binding region, even though it does with the binding sites of compound 4 as well as partially with compound 2.(73) Recently, the total syntheses of biselyngbyolide A (38, Figure 17) and compound 37 were achieved.(193−195) Compound 37 was further derivatized (39, Figure 17) with the aim of producing an antimalarial compound, based on the fact that its binding site in SERCA overlaps with the binding site of compound 4 and that compound 4, unlike compound 1, is capable of inhibiting the plasmodial SERCA orthologue, PfATP6.(195)

    5.4. Flavonoids

    Another group of SERCA inhibitors are flavonoids. These compounds are commonly found in fruit and vegetables, and their consumption is recommended as health-promoting and even anticancer,(196,197) and some have been tested in clinical trials (Tables 2 and 3). One of the reasons why flavonoids cause the above-mentioned effects may be SERCA inhibition. The first flavonoid to be found to interact with SERCA was quercetin(198) (40, Figure 18). Eventually, multiple flavones, flavanones, and isoflavones were screened for their potential SERCA-inhibiting properties and their SAR was determined.(70) Three of the tested flavones, 3,6-dihydroxyflavone (41, Figure 18), compound 40, and galangin (42, Figure 18), were found to inhibit the rabbit SERCA1a with IC50 values of 6.1, 8.9, and 8.9 μM, respectively. The position and a minimal amount of two hydroxyl groups were found to be crucial to the inhibitory activity of rabbit SERCA1a. While compound 41 inhibits porcine SERCA2b with similar potency as the rabbit SERCA1a, both compounds 40 and 42 showed a decreased potency.(70) Subsequent work by Ogunbayo and Michelangeli (2014)(199) showed that the inhibitory effects of compounds 40–42 can be described by cooperative inhibition with Hill coefficients of 1.8, 2.3, and 2.2, respectively. Although all three flavonoids stabilized SERCA preferentially in the E1 state, they affected slightly differently the binding of Ca2+ ions; compound 40 decreased the affinity of the ATPase for Ca2+ ions; on the other hand, compounds 41 and 42 decreased the rate of dissociation of the Ca2+ ions. The phosphorylation of SERCA was slowed down by compounds 42 and 40, the latter of which reduced also the rate of the dephosphorylation step. Furthermore, at least two flavonoid-binding sites that may take part in the cooperative inhibition of SERCA were predicted for compound 40; one of them is in the nucleotide-binding domain and the other is at the interface of the nucleotide-binding domain and the actuator domain.(199) Further research into compound 40 derivatives was done by Blaškovič et al.(200,201) Contrary to the findings of Ogunbayo et al.,(70) the IC50 value of compound 40 was equal to 150 μM while diquercetin (43, Figure 18) almost abolished the SERCA activity at the same concentration. Out of another eight tested quercetin derivatives, only 1,4,5-tri(chloropivatoyl)quercetin (44, Figure 18) possessed significant inhibition properties. The remaining derivatives did not exhibit any effect at concentrations up to 50 μM; above that, weak inhibitory or moderate stimulatory effect on SERCA activity was observed.(201) Nevertheless, the derivative compound 43 showed marked improvement in SERCA-inhibiting activity.(200)
    Another flavonoid examined for SERCA inhibitory activity was rutin and its fatty acid derivatives(40) (45, Figure 19). Rutin can protect SERCA from the inhibitory effect resulting from treatment of SERCA with hypochloric acid or peroxynitrite.(202,203) Fatty acids are prospective moieties for compound modifications due to their lipophilic properties and related interaction with lipid membranes. Unmodified rutin showed no inhibitory properties at concentrations up to 150 μM; however, rutin stearate, rutin linoleate, and rutin arachidonate exhibited IC50 values of 35, 25, and 23 μM, respectively. Furthermore, all prepared rutin acyl derivatives continued to inhibit SERCA with similar IC50 values even in the presence of ionophore ionomycin. Molecular docking studies identified that Glu-90, Glu-771, Thr-778, Thr-848, and Lys-297 in SERCA1 (Figure 2) are the key interacting partners of acylrutins. As Glu-771 is a part of the Ca2+ ions binding site I,(16) rutin derivatives appear to act by blocking the Ca2+ ion binding, an effect that is enhanced by the hydrophobic fatty acyl chain.(40) The overall biological activities and synthesis of rutin derivatives are summarized in ref (204).
    SERCA-inhibitory properties were also shown for epigallocatechin-3-gallate (46, Figure 20), which is the most common catechin found in Camelia sinensis leaves (green tea). Compound 46 interacts preferentially with the E2 state of SERCA, and its IC50 value toward SERCA activity is 12 μM. The key moiety of compound 46 for SERCA inhibition is apparently the gallate, since the inhibitory effect of nonesterified epigallocatechin is significantly lower.(86)
    While considerable effort was exerted on describing the effect of the above-mentioned flavonoids on SERCA, these compounds are known to show multiple biological activities and were recently classified among pan-assay interfering compounds(205) (PAINs; for details on the classification, see ref (206)). Therefore, although the compounds can be active against SERCA, they may not be suitable as drug leads.

    5.5. Curcumin

    Curcumin (47, Figure 21), a yellow polyphenolic pigment from the spice turmeric (Curcuma longa) and for long time used in Chinese traditional medicine, is another SERCA inhibitor, which is known for its anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, antiprotozoal, and anticancer properties. On the basis of SERCA activities, compound 47 has been reported as an inhibitor promoting a biphasic response, thus being a noncompetitive SERCA inhibitor with respect to ATP at concentrations up to 10 μM and a competitive inhibitor at higher concentrations.(82) It can bind at a single SERCA site with the affinity of >1 μM or at two SERCA sites with differing affinities (0.5 and 10 μM).(82) The binding site of compound 47 in SERCA is a hydrophobic pocket surrounded by M3 and M5. It was revealed that compound 47 interacts with SERCA mainly through hydrophobic interactions and stacking with Phe-256.(207) It stabilizes the enzyme in E1 conformational state and prevents ATP from binding. Some research groups claim that compound 47 is a subtype-nonspecific SERCA inhibitor,(82) while others reported some SERCA isoform selectivity: inhibition of SERCA1b and 3a with similar potencies (Ki values of 5.8 ± 1.6 μM and 8.6 ± 2.5 μM, respectively) but inhibition of SERCA2b with a markedly reduced potency (53 ± 6 μM).(69)
    Similar to other SERCA inhibitors, compound 47 exerts anticancer activity,(208) which has been demonstrated by promoting apoptosis in cells derived from various tumors, e.g., breast, lung, ovarian, and colon carcinoma and liposarcoma.(209−214) Compound 47 triggers the cell cycle arrest and apoptosis by evoking elevation of Ca2+ concentration in cancer cells but not in normal cells.(213,215) It was also reported that it induces ER stress and UPR response via SERCA2 inhibition in cells from liposarcoma and thyroid cancer, followed by caspase-3 and caspase-8 cascade-dependent apoptosis.(214,216) Moreover, antiangiogenic and antimalarial activities (PfATP6 inhibition of chloroquine-sensitive and resistant strains) were also reported for compound 47 and its novel derivatives.(217−222) Even though all of the above might seem medicinally promising and despite the fact that compound 47 has undergone a number of clinical trials and a number of authors suggested its use in the treatment of liposarcoma,(214) pancreatic cancer,(223) or even cystic fibrosis(224) and that more stable derivatives (e.g., demethoxycurcumin(225)) are being evaluated, its real medicinal application is questionable. It is especially so for its polypharmacology, since compound 47 affects a number of other cell enzymes: Na+/K+-ATPase,(226) protein kinase C,(227) cyclooxygenase,(228) Ca2+-dependent endonuclease,(229) and others. This multitargeting could possibly be explained by the fact that compound 47 can adopt many different conformations, as suggested by Gupta et al. based on molecular docking studies,(230) or that its degradation products are the ones responsible for its biological activity, thus explaining such diverse mechanisms of action,(231) which has been enigma for years. Above that, a contradictory report was published by Nelson et al.,(232) who reported its poor low water solubility and bioavailability (t1/2 < 10 min at 37 °C, pH 7.2 in aqueous solution), high thiol reactivity, and also the fact that no double-blinded, placebo-controlled compound 47 clinical trials were successful; therefore, it is a very improbable lead.

    5.6. Peptides

    SERCA inhibitors are also found among animal-derived biological compounds. Mastoparan (48, Figure 22) is an amphiphilic tetradekapeptide from venom of the wasp.(87) Compound 48 elicits various effects on multiple cellular targets (for a review, see section 3 in ref (233)), including mobilization of cellular Ca2+ through SERCA inhibition (Ki of 1.00 ± 0.13 μM) and activation of ryanodine receptors.(92) Furthermore, compound 48 activates heterotrimeric G-proteins(92) and inhibits Na+/K+-ATPase at micromolar concentrations.(234) While compound 48 inhibits SERCA in the presence of the Ca2+ ionophore A23187, compound 48 also activates SERCA at submicromolar concentration in the absence of A23187. Compound 48 analogues from different wasp species inhibit SERCA with low micromolar Ki values.(87) SERCA inhibition by compound 48 and its analogues is the result of their ability to order their conformation, which is distorted in aqueous environment, to α-helix upon entering the lipid environment. The presence of compound 48 affects the binding of Ca2+ to SERCA, changing it from cooperatively biphasic to monophasic.(87) Besides natural compound 48 and its synthetic analogues, SERCA-inhibiting chimeric compound 48 derivatives were also prepared, incorporating vasopressin antagonist and galangin moieties. Both chimeric peptides with the vasopressin antagonist moieties are potent SERCA inhibitors with IC50 values even lower than compound 48 (0.27 ± 0.08 μM for vasopressin antagonist derivative M391, 0.61 ± 0.14 μM for vasopressin antagonist derivative M375 compared to 1.00 ± 0.13 μM for compound 48), and both derivatives also activate the ryanodine receptor.(92)
    Compound 48 is not the only animal venom peptide exhibiting SERCA inhibiting properties; also the peptide melittin (49, Figure 23) from bee venom is known to inhibit SERCA, albeit likely by a different mechanism that affects binding of Ca2+ to the ATPase and also includes inhibition of SERCA dephosphorylation.(235) A similar mechanism was identified for another polypeptide, myotoxin A (50, Figure 23) from the prairie rattlesnake Crotalus viridis.(236) Compound 50 is known to cause muscle degeneration, and its C-terminal peptide was also shown to cause half-maximal inhibition of the skeletal muscle SERCA at ∼20 μM concentration.

    5.7. Vanadate, a P-Type ATPase Inhibitor

    The inhibitory effect of (ortho)vanadate on SERCA has been known for decades.(237,238) However, the compound was initially discovered and considered to be a specific inhibitor of Na+/K+-ATPase at nanomolar concentrations.(239) In contrast, the inhibition of SERCA by vanadate occurs at 5–50 μM and is affected by the concentration of potassium ions as well as oxalate.(237) It should be noted, though, that vanadate is not a single compound but rather a complex mixture of the monomeric orthovanadate and oligomeric vanadate forms.(240) Although orthovanadate acts as a stable analogue of SERCA E2 transition state phosphate,(241) oligomeric vanadate specimens also contribute to SERCA inhibition.(240) In particular, decavanadate was recently found to preferentially bind to the nucleotide site of SERCA,(242) for which it competes with ATP as well as pyrophosphate.(243) This mechanism of action indicates that vanadate, though often utilized as SERCA inhibitor, is rather a nonspecific P-type ATPase inhibitor.

    5.8. Phenolic and Aromatic Synthetic Compounds

    Various phenolic compounds, some previously identified as endocrine disruptors and pollutants in the environment, were also identified as SERCA inhibitors. Industrial alkylphenols such as nonylphenol inhibit rat testicular Ca2+ ATPase (a mixture of nonmuscle SERCA isoforms) with IC50 value in the low micromolar range, e.g, nonylphenol 0.35 ± 0.10 μM.(88,89,244) Similarly, bisphenol compounds, particularly bisphenol A (51, Figure 24) and the brominated flame retardant tetrabromobisphenol A (52, Figure 24), were found to be potent SERCA inhibitors.(74,94,244,245)
    Another endocrine disruptor, the artificial medically prescribed estrogen diethylstilbestrol (53, Figure 24), was formerly known to block proton translocation by H+-ATPases at micromolar concentrations,(246) but compound 53 also acts as a SERCA inhibitor with IC50 value of ∼15 μM.(247) A more recent study on compound 53 by Kirk et al.(75) arrived at a similar result for SERCA from rabbit SR (IC50 value of 14 ± 4 μM) and evaluated the inhibition of SERCA from fish liver microsomes (IC50 value of 7 ± 3 μM). Fish-derived SERCA is also sensitive to inhibition by phenolic compounds, e.g., the IC50 value for nonylphenol is 4 ± 2 μM.(75)
    SERCA-inhibiting properties were also detected for a cationic aromatic compound 1,3-dibromo-2,4,6-tris(methylisothiouronium)benzene(248) (54, Figure 25). Several isothiouronium compounds were initially synthesized as cation analogues for the study of Na+/K+-ATPase,(249) and compound 54 competitively inhibits this enzyme with Ki of 0.32 μM. Later, compound 54 was found to also competitively inhibit SERCA with a Ki of 20 μM. Unlike compounds 1 and 2 which stabilize the E2 state of SERCA and thus disable SERCA reactivation, compound 54 interferes with the conformational switch required for Ca2+ release into ER and results in reduced formation of the E2-P state.(67)
    Besides environmental pollutants, compounds identified previously as inhibitors or effectors of other enzymes or transporters are also occasionally identified as SERCA inhibitors. For example, CGP-37157 (7-chloro-5-(2-chlorophenyl)-1,5-dihydro-4,1-benzothiazepin-2(3H)-one, 55, Figure 26) had previously been considered a specific inhibitor of mitochondrial Na+/Ca2+ exchanger (NCX). However, this benzodiazepine derivative used clinically as tranquilizer actually acts on several other calcium handling targets in cells; namely, compound 55 increases ryanodine receptors’ (RyRs) calcium leakage and, above all, inhibits both cardiac and striated muscle SERCAs with IC50 values equal to 9.9 ± 2.0 μM for SERCA2a/cardiac microsomes and 6.6 ± 1.2 μM for SERCA1a/striated microsomes.(78) Combined activity toward RyRs and SERCA was also detected for 4-chloro-m-cresol, nevertheless, both with IC50 value at low millimolar concentrations.(71) Another promiscuous inhibitor is 2-aminoethoxydiphenyl borate, initially thought to modulate inositol-1,4,5-trisphosphate-sensitive Ca2+ channels(250) and store-operated Ca2+ entry,(251) which also inhibits SERCA at high micromolar concentrations.(68)
    Unlike the previously described compounds, for which SERCA inhibitory activity was identified, tetrahydrocarbazoles were rationally designed as PMA1 (plasma membrane ATPase 1; fungal H+-ATPase) inhibitors with the hope to create antifungal compounds.(252) Although the compound concentrations required to reach half-maximal growth inhibition of yeasts ranged from low micromolar (S. cerevisiae, Candida albicans) to micromolar (Candida krusei) and were not particularly effective against Candida glabrata, incidentally, some of the 12 compounds inhibit mammalian SERCA or mammalian Na+/K+-ATPase with even greater potency than their initial target PMA1, exhibiting submicromolar to low micromolar IC50 values. Therefore, further modification would be required to optimize these compounds into potential drug candidates.(252)

    5.9. Established Medicinal Compounds and Their Derivatives

    Besides the development within these main groups of SERCA inhibitors, other SERCA-inhibiting compounds have recently been discovered, some of which are already in clinical use. For example, the antiparasitic compound ivermectin (56, Figure 27) used worldwide as veterinary as well as human medication(253) was initially found to inhibit SERCA(254) in brain microsomes and skeletal muscles with IC50 values of 7 and ∼15 μM, respectively.(84) Moreover, compound 56 activates also RyRs in planar bilayers.(254) Unlike compound 1, which binds the E2 state of SERCA, compound 56 stabilizes the E1 state, blocking the release of Ca2+ ions into ER. However, it was later discovered that compound 56 does not inhibit only the SERCA-type of P-ATPases but also the Na+/K+- and H+/K+-ATPases(255) at similar concentrations. Therefore, compound 56 acts a nonspecific P-type ATPase inhibitor.(255) Altogether, the inhibition of P-type ATPases by compound 56 occurs at concentrations higher than those that are currently therapeutically achieved during regular treatment with compound 56. Nevertheless, the inhibition of P-type ATPases may be a source of possible adverse effects associated with repurposing of compound 56.
    Certain immunosuppressive drugs also act as SERCA inhibitors. The cyclic undecapeptide cyclosporine A (57, Figure 28) was also found to inhibit SERCA, although it is only effective on the skeletal muscle SERCA1a isoform (IC50 value of 50 μM) but not on the cardiac SERCA2a or brain microsomal SERCA2b.(84) The macrolide rapamycin (58, Figure 28), which is otherwise known to inhibit the mammalian target of rapamycin kinase (mTOR, reviewed in ref (256)), also inhibited the skeletal muscle SERCA1a with IC50 value of ∼75 μM, and at high concentration (200 μM), compound 58 caused ∼80% inhibition of SERCA2b in brain microsomes.(84) Interestingly, the already mentioned (section 4) yeast SERCA orthologue Pmr1 is also a regulator of the yeast TOR signaling,(257) the deletion of which results in compound 58 resistance in yeast.
    Physiologically, SERCA is regulated by several polypeptides (section 1); however, in contrast to the plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), SERCA is not regulated by calmodulin. Surprisingly, a number of calmodulin antagonists inhibit SERCA at micromolar concentrations.(76) Among them are antipsychotics from the group of phenothiazines, the most effective of which is fluphenazine (59,Figure 29) followed by chlorpromazine (60, Figure 29) and trifluoroperazine (61, Figure 29, IC50 values of 15 ± 4, 23 ± 5, and 45 ± 7 μM, respectively). However, the most effective SERCA inhibitor among calmodulin antagonists are the imidazolium compound calmidazolium (62, Figure 29) with IC50 value of 0.5 ± 0.1 μM and the calmodulin-binding peptide (IC50 value of 7 ± 0.6 μM).(76)
    Anti-inflammatory drugs are also among medicinal compounds with SERCA-inhibiting activity. The cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitor celecoxib (63, Figure 30) and its derivative dimethylcelecoxib(85) (64, Figure 30), which is a potential anticancer agent,(85,258) both inhibit SERCA.(77,85) Furthermore, another nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, sulindac sulfide(259) (65, Figure 30) and even the antimycotic agent clotrimazole (66, Figure 30)(80,260) act as SERCA inhibitors. Compound 66 restricts the Ca2+ ion binding initiation step(80) as well as phosphorylation(80,260) which thereby inhibits SERCA with IC50 value of 35 μM. The half-maximal inhibiting concentration of compound 66 is comparable to the effect on mammalian Na+/K+-ATPase (K0.5 of 24–30 μM)(261) and also the gastric H+,K+-ATPase (IC50 value of 5.2 μM),(262) both of which are P2-type ATPases. This indicates the close structural similarity of P2-ATPase pumps and comparable inhibitory mechanism of compound 66. Subsequently, two compounds related to compound 66, 2-aminoquinolines N-((3-chlorophenyl)(4-(pyrrolidin-1-ylmethyl)phenyl)methyl)-7-chloro-4-aminoquinoline (NF1058, 67, Figure 30) and N-((3-chlorophenyl)(4-((4-(7-chloroquinolin-4-yl)piperazin-1-yl)methyl)phenyl)methyl)-7-chloro-4-aminoquinoline (NF1442, 68, Figure 30), were prepared and show even more potent SERCA-inhibiting activity, with IC50 values of 8 and 1.3 μM, respectively.(34) The disadvantage of compound 68, though, is its poor solubility, which prevents its detailed testing.
    SERCA inhibitor may be derived even from already utilized chemotherapeutics. Ethyl 2-amino-6-bromo-4-(1-cyano-2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-4H-chromene-3-carboxylate (HA 14-1, 69, Figure 31) is a small molecule Bcl-2 antagonist utilized in combination with other chemotherapeutics for the treatment of leukemia.(93) The stable analogue of compound 69, sHA 14-1 [ethyl-2-amino-6-phenyl-4-(2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-4H-chromene-3-carboxylate; 70, Figure 31] is also a small aromatic molecule that acts both as Bcl-2 protein family antagonist and as SERCA inhibitor with IC50 values of 29.2 ± 4.9 and 23.5 ± 4.2 μM for SERCA1a and SERCA2b, respectively. Compound 70 has similar kinetics to compound 1; however, its antimitochondrial action is less pronounced than in the case of the parental compound 69.(93) Recently, 2-amino-6-(3,5-dimethoxyphenyl)-4-(2-ethoxy-2-oxoethyl)-4H-chromene-3-carboxylate (CXL017, 71, Figure 31) was prepared as a derivative of compound 70. Compound 71 (Figure 31) also inhibits SERCA, with the (−)CXL017 isomer being the most active (IC50 = 13.5 ± 0.5 μM). Furthermore, (−)CXL017 shows synergistic effect with the known SERCA inhibitors 1, 2, and 4 in resistant cells from acute promyelocytic leukemia (HL60/MX2).(83)

    6. Conclusion and Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A giant leap in the research has been made since the identification of the SERCA protein. Its function has been described, and SERCA inhibition has shown to be a very potent approach for induction of cell death of cancer cells in vitro. Well over a decade ago, the well-known SERCA inhibitor, compound 1, became a new drug lead in cancer treatment and its peptide derivative, compound 3, has recently been successful in late-stage clinical trials for treatment of solid tumors. One of the issues hindering wider use and further development of compound 1 is its limited availability from natural sources, to which several approaches and intense effort have been devoted. The success with the development of compound 1 prompted further intense interest in SERCA inhibitors, and soon, several of already known but often less thoroughly investigated SERCA inhibitors gained attention and became new leads in drug development investigations. This is the case of compound 3, a compound related to compound 1, as well as compounds 2, 4, and even 45. In recent years, several new and potent SERCA inhibitors were discovered, such as biselyngbyasides. SERCA inhibition was detected for a wide spectrum of structurally different compounds, some of which are even present in food while others are environmental pollutants. Furthermore, certain compounds already in clinical use have been found, besides their main therapeutic activity, to also inhibit SERCA. This could contribute to their therapeutic effect or their side effects and also potentially be developed for cancer treatment. At the same time, not all discovered SERCA inhibitors are necessarily prospective drug leads, as they may be far from specific in their choice of intracellular targets. A significant aspect to be considered for further development of SERCA inhibitors is the potential cross-reactivity of inhibitors with other P2-ATPases. Finally, ensuring correct cellular targeting of SERCA inhibiting drugs remains of utmost importance due to the ubiquitous and vital role of SERCA, and in that, significant refinements are still needed.

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
